captions.text:
Living with a black dog a guide for
partners
carers and sufferers.

What not to say or do. You may well be
right when you say

"It's all in your head!" but don't say it,
leave that up to the professionals
"Be a man!" this certainly doesn't help,

Especially if they are one already.
Depression is an illness,

not a sign of weakness. Don't be an
armchair general who gives unfounded advice

and orders. Being thoughtful and kind
will never go amiss.

Don't try and jolly them along, it can often
make them feel worse.

Don't point out that there are people in
this world far worse off than them.

It just adds to their feelings of guilt
and hopelessness.

Good things to say and do. Be sensitive
about how you approach the subject;

a lot of people aren't used to talking about
their mental health, or lack of it.

Crossing that line
simply means you care.
Try not talking

Instead grow your ears and open your
heart

Really being there for someone without
opinion or judgment
is one of the best gifts you can ever give.

Encourage them to seek a professional
opinion. An offer to help find a good doctor,

make an appointment and even going with
them, can be hugely beneficial
Encourage any former regular exercise

Fitness robs the dog with its power. Help
them develop a strategy to simplify
their life
both at home and at work.

Stress is one of the biggest drivers of
depression.
Less stress means less dog

Make them a ditch the dog box. Encourage
them to fill it with favorite photographs,

letters, anything that reminds them
of what's good in their life.

Include a "Dog Journal" Here they can
plot how they are feeling

acknowledge progress, record the things
the are grateful for

and set doable goals. Embracing the black
dog

Agree to a course of action to get rid
of the Black Dog
An ignored dog can become a big problem
Learn about the condition together;

knowledge is power and validation is a
great healer

A united front is crucial in getting the
Black Dog to move on
As a caregiver, compassion

empathy and understanding are vital, but
recognize that you alone

don't have the power to rescue your loved
one. Professional help is
often what's needed

Finding the right doctor can make all
the difference to a healthy recovery

If they're going to tell someone their
problems, it should be someone they respect

and feel comfortable with. Don't be
afraid to go for an initial assessment

and don't feel committed to continue if it
doesn't feel right. "“You can also see a nurse, a counsellor or a health-care worker"

If it suggested you take
anti-depressants

do your research. Know the facts and ask
your doctor plenty of questions

A big obstacle for seeking professional
help

is the cost. Help them realize that the
cost of not getting the right help

can be considerably higher: it can cost
marriages
friendships jobs and even life itself

Some simple rules of engagement and
agreement

Agree that there is a Black Dog in the
midst

and things may have to change
temporarily

Agree that no one can help them until
they fully commit to helping themselves
Agree to be gentle and respectful

with one another during this time. Agree
to check-in with each other

on a regular basis. Agree to communicate
honestly and openely.

Agree to the course of
action

set by the doctor and to review progress
regularly
Self-preservation for the caregiver

It can be difficult not to take anger,
criticism

negativity and apathy personally.  It's
important not to buy into it

accept that it's the depression barking, not
the person you care for.

Being overexposed to someone else's
Black Dog can begin to rub off.

Misery loves company so try not to get
sucked into the vortex

It's really important to recognize and
honor your own needs
limitations and boundaries.

Difficult situations a better dealt with
when you are calm and in the moment
Yoga, meditation and mindfulness

are great tools for achieving calmness and
control. Join a support group

There's nothing like being in a room
full of people who understand and share
your story

It's important to get out and do your
own thing

and be with friends. Friends may not be
able to solve your problems

but they can offer incredible support,
comfort, wisdom
and laughter.  A Black Dog in

any relationship can be confronting,
frightening

and frustrating but navigated
together, the bond can become

deeper richer and better for it.  And
finally

the most important aspect in this
tourney is to constantly remind each other
it will pass
it will pass
it will pass

If you have a Black Dog in your life, get
help, be helped
and always hold onto hope.

comments.text:
This week is Depression Awareness Week, you may have seen the "I have a 
black dog, his name was depression" video I shared earlier this week. 
Today's animated video is a guide for partners, carers and sufferers of 
depression. It advises those living with and caring for people with 
depression on what to do, what not to do, and where to go for help. 
#depression   #counselling   #mentalhealth   #mentalhealthawareness  ﻿

These videos are akin to teaching juniors to read & write while wrapping 
them up in cotton wool.

comments.author: Polina Filipova

comments.text:
Depression is not a black dog. Black dogs are not guilty of their colour, 
or our depression.
Depression is a "real" shadow inside you, that unbalance you, that can 
put you down, and pretends to be your best and only friend at the same time.
It wins if you don't learn to be happy in all circunstances, bad or good.
It wins if you don´t grow up emotionaly.
It wins if your body doesn't produce the right substances in your brain.
Emotions are the key, positive emotions are the bridge to a better health. 
and to self improvement.
Every living being is a potential victim of depression.
Everyone has inside a "doctor jekill and a mister hyde".
We have to act and we have to live for the victory of love and kyndness.﻿

comments.text:
It is dificult, but is not impossible.
This learning process is a long way with many milestones,  where human 
being is achieving personal goals. Everyone have them, even when they don't 
have the counscience of it.
Even an "healthy" life is not very diferent from a fight betwen light and 
shadow, or in a optimistic view, a process of self improvement, and 
enlightening achievment .
There is a character in "The magic mountain" of Thomas Mann, that  prefers 
to "die on the plain", he prefers to live fighting, even suffering, even 
having difficulties, but having the hapiness that all life allways have, 
even the hapiness people don't want to see or feel.
Sometimes people feel confortable, feeling bad.
Hapiness is not an easy emotion.
Human kind have to learn to be counscient of all colours of life.
Life is not a "fary tale", but it is not also only blak, grey or white.
comments.author: Maria Nascimento

comments.author: hplexmark1

comments.text:
Agree. My depression was never acknowledged in my family. It was attributed 
to "acting up", "being horrible" et cetera. My sister was thought that I 
was a person who simply "acts up" and "gets horrible for no reason". We are 
middle aged now, and instead of having important and close relationship 
with her, I have an estranged sibling who still reminds me that I am 
"acting up" and "behaving horribly". A book explaining to a child what 
depression is, how to deal with it, might have changed that.

My two teenage children are aware of what depression is, thanks to the 
"Black Dog" book. I wish there was a simple version of it that would help 
my youngest son understand it, because he knows something's wrong, and he 
is not able to comprehand what it is.
comments.author: thePix3lchick

comments.text: Good to know.﻿
comments.author: Susan Narducci

comments.text:
Let me give you an example of something that might start off with simple 
stress.
And all small things might seem trivial and manageable at first becomes a 
lifes worst burdain.

As a person who has carried the weight of an endless amount of stress and 
my surrounding not understanding my situation. (before the depression) I 
have carried with me the "black dog" with me from as long as i can 
remember. It started with the ritual bullying from the age of 6-8. Onto 
becoming more aware of my own situation in teens and my "friends" dropping 
me due to social status. At the age of 12 I started to think I was not 
allowed to sob or cry. I days consisted of waking up, going to school and 
face bullying alone, coming home in a situation where we where struck by a 
lot of cancer in the family and feeling alone there with no one to talk to 
because my friends already left me.

I burried my emotions to the points I only felt stress and anger. No more 
ways to get happy, no more ways to get sad. I forgot to mention my school 
refused to do a dyslexion test and i was send to the lowest highschool 
level while right now if i do an IQ test I score just into the gifted area. 
I spend my life on highschool not doing a single thing but dealing with 
bullying and not even having to study. At the age of 18 at my college I 
started to feel the presure... i just could not study anymore I could not 
keep my mind focussed at all. Things went downwards and downwards. Within 
the year the college, my family and and social workers of my college send 
me home to get help.

So I got help, people tried to give me help making me see I was sick. But 
at this point I was so far in denial that the only problem I could see was 
an overdoses of stress. I dived into online gaming and met a wonderful girl 
who lives on the other side of the world. She has her own deal of problems 
sure. But for the first time in my live, i felt some one understood me. At 
this time my official help gave me medication. That medication was supposed 
to be without side effects. It mind numbed me, I did not even see it... 1,5 
years later I look in the mirror I see myself extremely fat (i used to be 
normal posture). I browse the web and apparently this medication in some 
cases causes extreme weight gain. I now several years later managed to get 
a part of my life on my tracks. My best friend from across the world 
managed to regain me my emotions, yet the drawback.... i fallen in love 
with her. Now I have to get out of the cycle of hating myself for standing 
still, hating myself for being outcasted while i was young by people around 
me, and hating myself for the way I look. Doing anything does indeed take a 
great deal of strength.

The only joy I find in life right now is my love for my friend, but she 
cannot/will not return it because of her own situation making it more then 
just difficult. So my only joy becomes a frustration. I try to help myself 
and let myself be helped. But my black dog has grown not into the average 
dog size its a full car sized dog and fighting it takes its toll to the 
point i sometimes just fall back.

!! The point I try to make with this story. !!
If you are/or know a person who seems fine, it might be your kid your 
husband or wife or your friend. But you notice they start acting slightly 
different. It might be because they try to shoulder more then they can 
carry. They might seem fine for now and  i agree i was extremely 
independent before this happend. But if you do not stop and ask yourself if 
that simple stress isnt more then just a bad day. You might end up where I 
am fighting a battle (practically what feels like alone) against a problem 
that might have been kept in control if some one or I would just have seen 
it faster.﻿
comments.author: Redisia

comments.text:
I can greatly relate to that. I don't feel like making a long post like 
yours, but one of my first discoveries towards realizing what has happening 
was this Carl Jung quote " The greatest and most important problems of life 
are all in a certain sense insoluble. They can never be solved, but only 
outgrown." So yeah it feels like a neverending battle, day after day, while 
trying to keep hope that at some point it will get better. I hope it gets 
better for you soon.
comments.author: Tolis Kou

comments.text:
I hope she gets better soon, I hope she finds something or someone to reach 
out for. A beacon light as i call it. Good luck

I cred watching  this video. i had a black dog for 2 years. lost my 
partner, work. l learn what is starvation. fighting every day to not kill 
my self. my cure was changing everything in my life. plus i change my 
expectation how my life "should" look like. there is no expectation!!! i 
don't need family. big home. nice car.  When i stop chasing those thing 
they just came to me. now i got great supporting partner. live in tight 
studio. but happy and alive. black dog can come back but im ready to take 
him one more time. because i cant be more depressed then i already was!!!!﻿

comments.text:
Depression is sometimes referred to as the "Black Dog". Just like a real 
dog, it needs to be embraced, understood, taught new tricks, and ultimately 
brought to heel.

The video *“Living with a black dog”* is a guide for partners, carers and 
sufferers of depression. It advises those living with and caring for people 
with depression on what to do, what not to do, and where to go for help.

#depression   #depressionawareness   #depressionsymptoms  ﻿

comments.text:
'Millions of people around the world live with depression. “Living with a 
black dog” is a guide for partners, carers and sufferers of depression. It 
advises those living with and caring for people with depression on what to 
do, what not to do, and where to go for help.'﻿
comments.author: Brian Gray

comments.text:
What a great video, lots of really helpful practical advice here. Thanks 
for posting! ﻿
comments.author: The London Psychology Collective
